title: new 50 note scientists most likely stephen hawking ada lovelace rosalind franklin alan turing
story: Created with Sketch.Subscribe  registerSubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsPublic vote will help decide which person from world of science appear on new currency in coming weeksClick to followThe IndependentAn overlooked contributor to the discovery of the DNA double helix and the world’s most famous cosmologist are among those in the running to be the new face of the £50 note.The Bank of England has invited the public to submit the names of&nbspscientific figures they’d like to appear on the new banknote, with a decision set to be announced in six weeks.A shortlist will be drawn up by an expert committee including space scientist Maggie Aderin-Pocock and physicist Simon Singh, with the final decision to be made by the Bank’s governor, Mark Carney.But who are the favourites to&nbspadorn&nbspthe new £50 notes, and what have been their contributions to science and UK society?Many people’s favourite to win will undoubtedly be the recently deceased Hawking, a true scientific superstar whose contributions to science extended far beyond his own discipline.Particle physicist and TV presenter Professor Brian Cox expressed his support for Hawking on the new note,&nbsptweeting: “He made invaluable contributions over half a century to our understanding of cosmology, the early universe and black holes.”Professor Cox added that the former Cambridge academic has inspired thousands of scientists and millions of people through his books and lectures, “me included”.Hawking gave his name to the radiation emitted by black holes, advanced studies of the universe’s origins&nbspand penned the bestselling popular science book A Brief History of Time to transmit ideas from his discipline to more than 10 million readers.Franklin’s work as an X-ray crystallographer at King’s College London produced images that contributed to James Watson and Francis Crick’s identification of the DNA double helix.In the years following her death in 1958, her crucial work has been recognised by many including Watson and Crick themselves, but Franklin was not included in the Nobel Prize the duo went on to win four years later.Franklin’s story is now seen as a cautionary tale about the ways the contributions of women have been ignored over the course of scientific history.A place on the £50 note would be seen by many as a fantastic way to honour a scientist who was never given the recognition she deserved in her lifetime.Katherine Mathieson, chief executive of the British Science Association, mentioned Franklin along with palaeontologist Mary Anning as potential faces for the new notes.“They were both underrecognised in their lifetime and now we could set the record straight and recognise the huge achievements they made,” she said.Another figure seen as an overlooked&nbspscientific pioneer from a time when women were not traditionally included in science, Lovelace is often described as the world’s first computer programmer.The daughter of poet Lord Byron, Lovelace was a mathematician who worked on Charles Babbage’s proposed computer, the Analytical Engine.Lovelace translated an article by an Italian military engineer concerning the engine, adding an elaborate set of notes that contain what some have described as the first ever computer program – an algorithm intended to be carried out by a machine.Like Franklin, Lovelace has only recently been recognised for her contribution, and her addition to the new £50 would therefore be a fitting tribute for someone who was not recognised in their lifetime.In his role as a codebreaker during the Second World War, Turing played a major part in helping defeat Nazi Germany by providing the allied forces&nbspwith information that gave them the upper hand in key operations.His work at Bletchley Park during the war cracked the German messages sent by the Enigma machine, and is regarded as making key contributions to the fields of computer science and artificial intelligence.Turing was convicted in 1952 under anti-homosexuality laws, leading to him accepting chemical castration and ultimately taking his own life two years later.Though he was posthumously pardoned in 2013, many will surely see a place on the currency as a way to honour his legacy.As the only British woman to become a Nobel science laureate, Hodgkin would be another perfect addition to the UK’s currency, and one who many people are perhaps not familiar with.The chemist won the prize in 1964 for her pioneering work that helped unravel the 3D structure of important substances such as insulin.Her nomination was backed by Royal Society president Venki Ramakrishnan, who said: “I would personally pick Dorothy Hodgkin, the only female Briton to have won a science Nobel Prize.”“We can thank Dorothy for revealing the three-dimensional structures of many biologically important molecules such as penicillin, insulin and vitamin B12, as well as inspiring several generations of leading crystallographers.“She was also a remarkable inidual who championed science in developing countries.”Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a I got kicked out (of school), not for anything crazy, he said. It's going to sound way crazier than it was, I put loads of chairs on another student.Stormzy on his piano lesson with Paul McCartney: 'It was incredible'It sounds mad but we were messing around, it was horseplay and I just put loads of chairs on the student so he was trapped. Enough to entrap the whole human body. It was a spontaneous attack actually.It was just some banter, as you do. It sounds crazy but it was just jokes.Stormzy&nbspadmitted that he had got in trouble prior to the chair incident, resulting in his removal from the school.It was like the 100th strike, you don't get kicked out for putting chairs on someone, he added.The rapper referred to his younger self as just a little s*** and said his mother was left fuming.Created with Sketch. Show all 10Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Todd Haynes followed his glam rock pseudo-biopic Velvet Goldmine (1998) with this inventive exploration of the many sides of Bob Dylan. Six actors – Cate Blanchett, Heath Ledger, Christian Bale and Ben Whishaw among them – portrayed Dylan at different stages of his career as part of an appropriately freewheelin’ approach to narrative.To convince director Oliver Stone to give him the part of Jim Morrison, Val Kilmer undertook hours of extensive research into his hero, learning 50 songs to mimic his singing voice. When the surviving members of the Doors assembled to hear a recording of Kilmer, none could tell which was the impersonation and which the real Morrison. The Doors was not loved by all but the great Kyle MacLachlan and Meg Ryan were memorable in supporting roles as keyboardist Ray Manzarek and Morrison's girlfriend Pamela Courson respectively. story: Created with Sketch.Subscribe  registerSubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsLincolnshire native&nbspcompletes epic challenge in 157&nbspdays – during which his&nbsptongue began to disintegrate because of prolonged exposure to seawaterClick to followThe IndependentA Grantham man has become the first person to swim around Great Britain’s&nbspentire 1,780-mile coastline.Ross Edgley&nbspfinished the epic journey in Margate&nbspat around 9am, having been joined by 300 swimmers for his last mile.The adventurer, who has previously rope-climbed the height of Everest and swum 100km through the Caribbean Sea while tied to a log, swum for up to 12 hours each&nbspday.Why wild swimming in Slovenia is the ultimate adventureMr Edgley had not set foot on dry land since he left Margate in June, only stopping to sleep on board his support catamaran.The strongman had hoped to complete his world-first in under 100 days but in the end the herculean task took him 157&nbspdays to finish.As well as battling strong currents and tides, the 33-year-old Lincolnshire swimmer also had to dodge jellyfish and storms as he slowly made his way around the coast.&nbspHe estimated that he had eaten about 500 bananas and consumed at least half a million calories to fuel his exertions.&nbspEach day he planned to eat the same number of calories found in five Christmas dinners.&nbspEdgley approaches Margate beach as he finishes his ‘Great British Swim’ (Red Bull Media House)Mr Edgley&nbspmade 11 miles of progress each day on average and the overall effort was the equivalent of completing 85 cross-Channel swims consecutively.&nbspIn August, 74 days into his challenge, he broke the world record for the longest staged sea swim. Now, he has extended that by a further 82 days.&nbspAs cheering crowds greeted his return to Margate on Sunday morning, he said&nbsphe was delighted with the support he had received.&nbsp“This is amazing. In his conference speech, leader Vince Cable is expected to elaborate on his plans for a Movement for Moderates An early Banksy mural has been accidentally painted over during renovations. The mural has been on the shop front on Park Row in the artist's hometown of Bristol since the 1990sIn June, however, Mr Banks told&nbspMPs&nbspon the Commons Digital, Culture, Media and Sport (DCMS) Committee&nbspthat Rock Services was “just a service company” and “just delivers the cash”. He said the “actual loan came from another one of my companies”.Asked repeatedly by Mr Marr&nbspwhat the other company was, the businessman insisted the money had come only from Rock Services.&nbspHe rejected the Electoral Commission’s suggestion that some of the money could have come&nbspfrom Isle of Man-based company Rock Holdings, which owns Rock Services. This would be potentially illegal because, under UK law,&nbspcampaign donations can only be made by firms&nbspregistered in the UK.Mr Banks&nbspsaid the probe into Leave.EU’s funding was “politically motivated” and came after pressure from “a group of vicious Labour MPs who have grouped together with  and the Financial Times to try to undermine Brexit”.The BBC’s decision to host&nbspMr Banks on&nbspthe&nbspshow&nbspprompted outrage from other political figures.In a typically aggressive performance, the Brexiteer&nbsplashed out at DCMS&nbspcommittee chairman Damian&nbspCollins, who has&nbspbeen highly critical of him.Asked why he had written to Mr Collins’ constituents in Folkestone and Hythe calling the MP a “snake in the grass”, Mr Banks replied: “Well, he is.”Claims have been made that Mr Banks misled&nbspMr Collins’ committee&nbspin relation to whether staff at another of his insurance companies had worked on the Leave.EU campaign.According to The Observer, leaked emails suggest&nbspemployees of Eldon Insurance worked on the campaign without this being declared as official&nbspspending.Mr Collins suggested the emails appeared to “flatly contradict” what Mr Banks had told his committee in June.&nbspAsked about the matter, Mr Banks told Andrew&nbspMarr: “That was reported to the Electoral Commission. People that&nbspdid work from Eldon were transferred over on short-term contracts&nbsplegally and it was reported through the Electoral Commission in the right way.”The Independent has launched its #FinalSay campaign to demand that voters are given a voice on the final Brexit deal.Sign our petition hereShare your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our Community Guidelines.You may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or inciteful language is not acceptableDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Follow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - be the first to add your thoughtsJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our Community Guidelines.You may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or inciteful language is not acceptableDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Follow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no Independent Minds comments yet - be the first to add your thoughtsEnter your email to follow new comments on this article.Are you sure you want to submit this vote?Are you sure you want to mark this comment as inappropriate?Want to discuss real-world problems, be involved in the most engaging discussions and hear from the journalists? password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsDowning Street dismisses as&nbsp'speculation' reports PM has secured concessions from EU over Northern Ireland border issueClick to followIndy PoliticsTheresa May&nbsphas reportedly&nbspsecured concessions from Brussels to keep the whole of the UK in a customs union in the wake of&nbspBritain’s withdrawal from the&nbspEuropean Union.Reaching an agreement would&nbspprevent the need for&nbspNorthern Ireland&nbspto be treated differently from the rest of the UK, a main stumbling block during&nbspBrexit&nbspnegotiations.The “secret”&nbspdeal would avoid&nbspthe need for an Irish backstop and&nbspwould be written into the legally binding&nbspdeal, according to The Sunday Times.&nbspHowever, Downing Street has poured cold water on the report, calling it speculation.More than 70 business leaders back final say Brexit referendumEU slavery victims at risk of re-exploitation after BrexitBBC defends booking Brexit donor Arron Banks for Andrew Marr Brexit is putting Good Friday Agreement at risk, Varadkar saysMore Britons expected to travel abroad next year, despite BrexitThe EU has reportedly suggested a backstop post-Brexit customs arrangement covering all of the UK could give mainland Britain some scope to set trade rules.Preparations for a final deal were far more advanced than previously disclosed, the report said, and would lead to a document of 50 pages or more being published.The agreement would include an “exit clause” designed to convince Brexit-supporting MPs&nbspthat remaining in the customs union was only temporary, The Sunday Times&nbspsaid.Ms May’s cabinet will meet on Tuesday to discuss her plan, and she hopes there will&nbspbe enough progress by Friday for the EU to announce a special summit, the newspaper reported.The prime minister’s office&nbspdescribed the report as speculation&nbspbut claimed most of a deal on Britain’s exit from the bloc in March 2019 had been agreed.“This is all speculation,” a spokesman for Ms May said. “The prime minister has been clear that we are making good progress on the future relationship, and 95 per cent of the withdrawal agreement is now settled and negotiations are ongoing.”Meanwhile, more than 70 business figures are calling for a public vote on the final terms of Britain’s exit from the European Union, warning that the country faces “either a blindfold or a destructive hard Brexit”, the newspaper also reported.Companies are increasingly concerned about the prospect of Britain crashing out of the EU without an agreement, or fear that politicians will sign up to a deal that limits companies’ access to the continent’s markets.A new group called Business for a People’s Vote, which includes Justin King, former boss&nbspSainsbury’s, and John Neill, head of the car parts supplier Unipart, is to be launched as campaigners raise the pressure on politicians.“We are now facing either a blindfold or a destructive hard Brexit. Both these options will further depress investment,” the group said&nbspin a letter.“They will be bad for business and bad for working people. Given that neither was on the ballot in 2016, we believe the ultimate choice should be handed back to the public with a People’s Vote.”The government’s Brexit department said it was confident of securing a deal that works for businesses, and reiterated its opposition to a second referendum.“The people of the United Kingdom have already had their say in one of the biggest democratic exercises this country has ever seen, and the prime minister has made it clear that there is not going to be a second referendum,” a spokesman said.Additional reporting by ReutersThe Independent has launched its #FinalSay campaign to demand that voters are given a voice on the final Brexit deal.Sign our petition hereShare your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our Community Guidelines.You may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or inciteful language is not acceptableDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Follow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - title: brexit latest no deal irish border article 50
story: Created with Sketch.Subscribe  registerSubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsCreated with Sketch.Analysis:&nbspAs a compromise on the Irish border edges&nbspcloser, Europe Correspondent Jon Stone looks at what happens nextClick to followIndy PoliticsTailbacks: a vision of a no-deal Brexit? There may yet be a Brexit agreement on the Irish border. The latest whispers out of meetings in Brussels are that the EU is preparing to offer a compromise solution on the so-called “backstop”. Whether it will be enough for the UK remains to be seen.But let’s suppose it is, and a withdrawal agreement is signed. Does that prevent a no deal? Not exactly.There are two things that could still cause a no-deal Brexit. Both bring a huge degree of uncertainty.EU plans compromise on customs union to solve Irish borderThe first is the parliamentary vote. Theresa May, you may remember, has no majority in the House of Commons and needs help. How the DUP, Labour, and Conservative Eurosceptics&nbspvote will determine whether a deal passes parliament, even if it has been agreed between&nbspnegotiators.The second uncertainty is over the future trading relationship. An outline of this was supposed to have been agreed by now, but the timetable has slipped because of a lack of progress on Northern Ireland, which the EU insists must be dealt with first.&nbspIt is not widely understood that UK law states that this outline of the future relationship has to be presented to MPs before any vote on the withdrawal deal. But it is simply not clear how this will be possible.&nbspTheresa May’s Chequers plan has been dismissed, and she has rejected the EU’s options of a loose free trade agreement or Norway-style single market participation. Negotiations are practically at square one for this, with practically no time left.It is widely claimed that any document will have to be a fudge. But the EU said at the Salzburg summit that any outline must be specific – not just a list of vague aspirations.Brexit talks ‘close to a deal’ says DUP leader Arlene FosterGovernment urged to revive fishing for endangered tuna after BrexitArron Banks is hoping to become some kind of Brexit martyrUK construction dogged by Brexit uncertainty in OctoberHow agreement could be reached on anything substantial is unclear, and neither side looks able to back the other’s proposals. It’s possible the issue of the trading relationship could make a comeback and sink the whole thing.And yet, if we cannot sign a deal, Britain may still avoid heading over the cliff edge.&nbspThe government says emphatically it is prepared to go ahead with a no-deal Brexit, but the truth is the country is simply not prepared. The physical infrastructure needed is not in place and will take years to build, at ports, airports, and elsewhere.&nbspThere is certainly not a majority in the House of Commons for a no-deal, and the political damage to the government of going ahead with one far outweighs any benefit.However, there remains the option to revoke Article 50 – even temporarily – before March 29.&nbspEmpty supermarket shelves, grounded flights, and queues at ports are a prime minister’s worst nightmare. Desperation to avoid this at all costs means that a&nbsplast-minute government U-turn is more than just a possibility&nbsp– it’s likely.The Independent has launched its #FinalSay campaign to demand that voters are given a voice on the final Brexit deal.Sign our petition hereShare your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our Community Guidelines.You may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or inciteful language is not acceptableDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Follow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - be the first to add your thoughtsJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our Community Guidelines.You may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or inciteful language is not acceptableDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Follow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no Independent Minds comments yet - be the first to add your thoughtsEnter your email to follow new comments on this article.Are you sure you want to submit this vote?Are you sure you want to mark this comment as inappropriate?Want to discuss real-world problems, be involved in the most engaging discussions and hear from the journalists? story: Created with Sketch.Subscribe  registerSubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsAverage wages also rose by 3.1 per cent year-on-year, the fastest rate since 2009Click to followThe IndependentThe US construction sector added 30,000 new jobs in OctoberThe US jobs market continued to surge in October, adding 250,000 new jobs.That figure, reported by the Bureau of Labor&nbspStatistics (BLS), was 60,000 higher than the 190,000 Wall Street analysts had pencilled in.It was also higher than the average monthly gain of 211,000 over the past year.General Motors says Trump’s tariffs could threaten US jobsAnd average wages rose by 3.1 per cent year-on-year, the fastest rate since 2009.The unemployment rate was unchanged at 3.7 per cent, the lowest rate since 1969.The dollar index spiked in the wake of the data, rising to 96.322. It will serve as an opportunity for businesses to reach people, he said.WhatsApp update finally brings stickers to messaging appThe status feature is something like the stories tool that appears in Instagram and Facebook, as well as WhatsApp. It allows people to post updates that will appear to all of their friends, letting them share photos or text and then letting it disappear afterwards.WhatsApp has struggled to come up with ways to show its users ads: without a feed, like Instagram or Facebook, there are few places for them to be injected.When it dropped its subscription fee in 2016, the company posted a blog post making clear that ads would never interrupt your communication, further adding to the issues about how advertising could be shown within the app.But the status feature appears to have solved that problem, allowing WhatsApp to slide marketing posts in between updates from friends, like it does with Instagram stories.As well as serving as something like a feed, WhatsApp's status feature has quickly become a huge part of the app. It now has a huge number of users, and is more popular than many major apps like Snapchat.Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our Community Guidelines.You may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or inciteful language is not acceptableDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Follow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - story: Created with Sketch.Subscribe  registerSubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsControversial move purportedly designed to improve birth rateClick to followThe IndependentUnder the proposals, parents who have a third child between 2019 and 2021 would be given plots of state-owned farmland to run for 20 yearsItaly’s far-right government is planning to entice women into having&nbspmore children by offering families free farmland if they have a third child.The initiative purportedly&nbspaims to increase the country’s flagging birth rate, which is the lowest in Europe.&nbspBut critics have derided the idea as “neo-medieval” and reminiscent of efforts by the fascist dictator Benito Mussolini to boost Italy’s population in the 1920s and 1930s.Italy's budget crisis is a bigger threat to the EU than BrexitThe so-called “land for children” plan was created by the populist right-wing League party, which forms part of Italy’s hardline coalition government, and was included in the nation’s contentious budget.&nbsp“They say that Italians have few children and that something is needed to turn the trend around,” agriculture minister&nbspGian Marco Centinaio said.“That’s why the ministry wants to contribute, favouring rural areas in particular, where people still have children.”If the scheme is implemented, parents who have a third child between 2019 and 2021&nbspwould be given plots of state-owned farmland to run for 20 years.They would also be offered zero-interest loans of up to £175,000 if they chose to buy their first home next to&nbsptheir new smallholding.&nbspBut many are sceptical that the land for children plan would work. title: BBC biased budget today programme complaint theresa may conservative party
story: Mrs May&rsquos Conservative Party was incensed by the Corporation&rsquos news coverage of Chancellor Philip Hammond&rsquos Budget announcement, which was analysed by a former Labour Party head of policy.One enraged aide to the prime minister called &ldquothe most biased bulletin in history.The row came after a series of bulletins on the Today programme included bizarre claims from a left-wing think-tank that the budget mainly benefited the rich, The Sunday Times reports.The show&rsquos analysis said that &ldquodespite moves to end austerity, low and middle income families face a continued squeeze.BBC Weather: Winter FREEZE 'over for now' with Britain set to HEAT UPUK weather forecast: Met Office reveals huge temperature SURGEYet the BBC did not reveal to viewers the director of the think tank that provided the analysis, Resolution Foundation, was run by Ed Miliband's former head of policy Torsten Bell.A Conservative Party spokesperson told the Sunday Times: &ldquoIt is frankly astounding that on the morning after the Government cut taxes for 32million people, increased the national living wage to help 2.4million low-income earners, and invested &pound1.7billion more in Universal Credit, the BBC chose to lead its coverage on a report from a Leftwing think-tank that claimed only rich people would benefit.The programme aired on Tuesday and has since triggered a complaint from No 10, with the BBC refusing to apologise for its coverage, adding the analysis was clearly attributed to the Resolution Foundation.The BBC has faced mass criticism over bias reporting, particularly over its Brexit and election coverage.The row came after a series of bulletins on the Today programme (Image: )The BBC has faced mass criticism over bias reporting (Image: )Pakistan election 2018: BBC bias storm over interview with media bossBBC blasted for 'deliberately LYING' over coverage of Israeli strikes An independent report into the BBC's coverage of the historic week that Article 50 was triggered to leave the EU concluded that it was strongly biased against Brexit.The 2017 report by monitoring group News-Watch, which also looked at the Today programme, and found there was overwhelming negativity about Leaving the EU.During the six three-hour morning shows from Monday 29 March to Saturday 4 April, Today fielded 124 guests on Article 50 but only eight, 6.5 per cent, were given the space to make substantive arguments that the future for the UK outside the EU would yield significant benefits.The BBC argues that &ldquoimpartiality is at the heart of its journalism.

And it has endeared her to him even more.Another source said: &ldquoWhatever they felt inside, they&rsquove both put on a strong public face and not hidden away. title: royal news queen abdicate prince charles royal family
story: While most typical 21-year-olds nowadays are concerned about parties, fashion and social media, a young Princess Elizabeth made a promise on her 21st birthday to dedicate her life to the service of the Commonwealth.&nbspOn April 21 1947, the Queen delivered the historic speech, which was broadcast on the radio, while she was on a tour of South Africa with her parents King George VI and Queen Elizabeth and her younger sister Princess Margaret.&nbspShe said: &ldquoI declare before you all that my whole life whether it be long or short shall be devoted to your service and the service of our great imperial family to which we all belong.Despite being 92 and showing no signs of slowing down, the Queen has &ldquonever even contemplated abdication, according to Royal author Sarah Bradford.                What are the Royals doing this month? The Royal Family's NovemberQueen Elizabeth II made a public promise aged 21 to serve the Commonwealth until she dies (Image: Samir HusseinWireImage)According to a royal author, the Queen has never considered handing over power to Prince Charles (Image: Peter Nicholls - WPA PoolGetty Images)A YouGov poll conducted earlier this year, showed the Queen is the most commonly-sighted Royal, with 31 per cent of the British public saying they have either seen or met her in real life and more than half of over 65s saying they have caught a glimpse of the monarch.In April, it was announced that Prince Charles would succeed the Queen as the Head of the Commonwealth, after his mother had held the role since 1952.When Prince Philip announced his retirement from Royal duties in May 2017, questions were raised about the likelihood of the Queen joining him.&nbspBut the move meant the monarch is now frequently accompanied by younger members of the Royal family in place of the Duke of Edinburgh, which many believe has given the monarchy a fresh face and is seen to be more appealing to the younger generation.&nbspFour months after the death of her father, Queen Elizabeth II ascended to the throne at the age of 25, a year before the Coronation was held.

title: royal news queen elizabeth budget 2018 treasury
story: In its 2018 Budget, the UK Treasury said Queen Elizabeth II will get &pound82.4 million for the coming financial year to fund her royal duties. The rise trails behind Septembers&rsquos 2.4 per cent annual inflation rate and is the smallest increase to be awarded to Her Royal Highness since the UK changed its financing arrangement with the royal family six years ago.&nbspKnown as the Sovereign Grant, the package funded by taxpayers is given to the Queen by the Treasury and is 25 per cent of the revenue from the Crown Estate.&nbspPaid two years in arrears and reviewed every five years, it is given in exchange for her surrendering all profits from the Crown Estate to the UK government.&nbspThe Crown Estate is made of of a large number of properties owned by the royal family, including the entire UK seabed, almost all of Regent Street in London&rsquos West End and Ascot racecourse.Queen Elizabeth II has been given her lowest pay increase in recent years (Image: Max MumbyIndigoGetty Images)                The promise the Queen made which means she&rsquoll NEVER give up the throne                Queen invites Meghan&rsquos mum Doria Ragland for ChristmasPhilip Hammond, UK chancellor of the exchequer, holds the dispatch box containing the 2018 budget (Image: Chris RatcliffeBloomberg via Getty Images)Each year, it costs around &pound300 million to run the British monarchy, made up of both public and private funding.&nbspThe Queen, who is the longest-reigning monarch the UK has ever had, receives a substantial amount of private funding from the Privy Purse.&nbspThis money comes directly form the Duchy of Lancaster, the private estate made up of land and properties which is held in a trust.

title: brexit news tony blair theresa may brexit deal second referendum
story: The former prime minister, who walked away from frontline politics more than 10 years ago, insists it is now impossible for Mrs May to secure a good outcome for the country and warned of a public backlash that would last a political lifetime.Writing in today&rsquos Observer, Mr Blair said: &ldquoWe are approaching Brexit crunch time.&ldquoEveryone is going to come under intense pressure to agree a &lsquoreasonable deal&rsquo, Labour MPs especially.&ldquoThey should resist. There is no &lsquoreasonable deal&rsquo.                Brexit ALREADY offering boost to UK's economy                Remainer MPs planning to launch NEW PARTY by CHRISTMAS&ldquoThere is the pointless, the painful or fudge through postponement of the core issues.&ldquoEach option is bad. MPs should vote it down and give the people the final say.Mr Blair said MPs should be more worried about the consequences of inflicting a bad outcome on an electorate than being of voting against a Brexit deal which could be only weeks away.He described Mrs May&rsquos Chequers blueprint as &ldquomadness and said: &ldquoTime has not lessened my sense of the catastrophic effects of Brexit. It has increased it.Tony Blair has repeated his calls for a second Brexit referendum (Image: PA)Theresa May is detemined to stick to her Chequers plans (Image: PA)&ldquoMPs should vote against the deal, while saying to their constituents: &lsquoWe cannot, in all conscience, agree with this, but the final decision is yours.&rsquo&ldquoI promise them as someone who used to win elections: no one will lose their seat on this basis.&ldquoBut vote through a botched negotiation that you don&rsquot believe in and the backlash will last a political lifetime.Mr Blair, who won three terms in office before standing down as Labour leader in 2007 when handed power to Gordon Brown, argues the Government has tabled a series of &ldquoincompatible demands which has led to a negotiating impasse.                Labour MP sparks OUTRAGE over &lsquotasteless&rsquo and &lsquomisguided&rsquo joke                 Kate Hoey says no Brexit deal is 'NO PROBLEM' for BritainHe said: &ldquoThey want a frictionless border in Ireland. That can only happen if Northern Ireland remains in the customs union and single market, at least for goods and agricultural products. But they want the UK to leave the customs union and single market.&ldquoHowever, they also want Northern Ireland and Britain to be in the same relationship to Europe as each other.&ldquoAnd they made a rash commitment last December that the Northern Ireland issue would be resolved as a part of the withdrawal agreement, with the border frictionless and with a backstop to guarantee it. There is simply no answer to the Irish issue.The Irish border remains a major sticking point in exit negotiations with the Prime Minister rejecting the European Union&rsquos proposed backstop.Protesters took to the streets to demand a People's Vote (Image: PA)Mrs May insists no British Prime Minister could accept the backstop, which would effectively see a border implemented down the middle of the Irish Sea.The Prime Minister has also vowed to stick by her controversial Chequers plan, despite criticism from EU leaders and prominent Brexiteers in her own party.

title: snp new subway glasgow broken election promises scotland
story: The Subway currently serves the centre, west end and south-west of Glasgow (Image: NC)Ahead of the council elections 18 months ago, party leaders announced ambitious plans to build new lines on the underground network for the first time since 1896.The Subway currently serves the centre, west end and south-west of Glasgow, and the SNP pledged to investigate extending it to other parts of the city.In April last year, Councillor Kenny McLean said: &ldquoWe will look at a possible extension of the Subway and consider innovative funding methods, such as City Bonds, to fund this work.&ldquoThe subway is over 120 years old. It is high time that we look to connect communities in the north and east of Glasgow.                SNP attitude on Philip Hammond's tax cuts slated as 'disastrous'Transport experts have estimated the project could cost up to &pound5billion.The Nationalists also called for the Subway to be taken out of the hands of Strathclyde Passenger Transport and brought under full council control, with the backing of the SNP Government.Cllr McLean, now City Convener for Neighbourhoods, Housing and Public Realm, said: &ldquoThe Subway is entirely within Glasgow, it makes sense that the network is maintained by the City Government.However, there has so far been little or no progress on any of the ambitious plans, while the cash-strapped council is distracted by problems such as the massive bill to settle a long-running equal pay dispute.Last night, Glasgow&rsquos Labour leader, Councillor Frank McAveety, accused his successor of breaking her promise to voters.He said: &ldquoThis is another broken promise from Susan Aitken.&ldquoShe promised solutions but has instead delivered nothing.&ldquoThe SNP is failing to deliver for the people of Glasgow.Scottish Conservatives said the SNP was more focused on &ldquoplaying petty political games instead of doing the job voters expect of them.Glasgow MSP Annie Wells said: &ldquoAs always happens with the SNP, warm words and a grand plan have been followed by zero action.                SNP accused of starving Scots GPs of &pound660m of support                Plea to Sturgeon on tax rises after Budget boost for ScotlandScottish Conservative MSP Annie Wells (Image: Ken Jack - CorbisCorbis via Getty Images)&ldquoWhether it&rsquos at council or Scottish Government level, the Nationalists can never get on with the job at hand.Glasgow City Council insisted that improved transport links were &ldquocrucial to delivering our aspirations for Glasgow&rsquos social and economic prosperity.The local authority has appointed an expert group to look at the future of transport in the city, and the commission is expected to deliver its initial findings next month.A council spokeswoman said: &ldquoOver the course of the current council term, the city government has a number of transport plans which it will deliver.&ldquoExploring the viability of extending Glasgow&rsquos Subway as a long-term project was a manifesto pledge and remains part of that.

We found offences in 40 of these investigations: 25 of these investigations looked at leave campaigners and 15 looked at remain campaigners.&ldquoA small number of further investigations are ongoing outcomes will be published in due course.&ldquoWe take seriously any accusations or complaints of impartiality among Commissioners or staff.&ldquoTransparency and independence are central to our decision-making process. For this reason, we recently requested an independent review of Commissioner impartiality following recent complaints.&ldquoThe review found no evidence of wrong doing at the Commission and the complaints made were not upheld.&ldquoThe review found that we go to great lengths to achieve impartiality by both segregating the decision-making process between Commissioners and the executive where necessary as well as ensuring that any Commissioners with a conflict of interest recuse themselves from decisions that are taken.

title: Brexit news UK EU latest deal vote Theresa May Margaret Thatcher customs union
story: Prime Minister Theresa May has secured a secret Brexit deal with the EU which would keep the whole of the UK in the customs union to avoid a hard border in Ireland, according to the Sunday Times.The former Tory MP ripped into Mrs May and said she is &ldquonot a fighter like former Prime minister Conservative Margaret Thatcher.Speaking to Brexiteer Nigel Farage on LBC, Mr Mellor said: &ldquoThe trouble with Theresa May, she thinks one more concession and she will get a deal.&ldquoYou know, that is the worry. I believe that when she exposes this stuff, I think a lot of people will think &lsquoif you&rsquod fought harder and you&rsquod been a different sort of person&rsquo.                Aaron Banks: I'd REMAIN in EU rather than face May's SELL OUT                Theresa May makes SECRET DEAL with EU to keep UK in customs union&ldquoLet&rsquos go back to a cliche. I was Margaret Thatcher&rsquos youngest minister for four years. I served in her Government for nine years and another two under John Major.&ldquoMargaret Thatcher was a fighter.&ldquoTheresa May is not a fighter.&ldquoWould Margaret Thatcher be accepting a lot of this stuff? No, no, no, no.Brexit news: David Mellor said Margaret Thatcher would be  (Image: European Union&bullSky News&bullGetty)While in discussion with Mr Mellor, Nigel Farage warned Britain will not have taken back control after Brexit and could have to pay billions more to the Brussels bloc if it remains in the&nbspcustoms union with the EU.&nbspMr Farage said: &ldquoBasically, at the time of the next general election, we are going &ndash if she gets this deal through Parliament &ndash to be in a position where we have not taken back control, not taken back control of our fisheries, we are not able to make our own trade deals.&ldquoAnd, financially, it won&rsquot be &pound39billion we have given the EU, it will be something closer to &pound60billion.&ldquoSo, I have to say, to me, it doesn&rsquot give us any of the possible benefits of Brexit.&ldquoI know that school kids in 100 years will read we left the Treaty.&ldquoBut I think it needs to be opposed.The Prime Minister will reportedly warn Brexiteers that if they reject this deal they will be blamed for causing a potentially very difficult no deal scenario.The plan is aimed at securing the support of Remain MPs within the Conservatives ranks as well as some Labour ministers, and there would be an exit clause in a bid to win over Tory Brexiteers.The Prime Minister is said to be pushing to keep open the possibility of a Canada-style free trade deal with the EU in the future.Mrs May is expected to discuss the plan with Cabinet on Tuesday and agree on the final details with the EU at a special summit later this month.But Downing Street last night claimed the report was simply &ldquospeculation.A spokesman for the Prime Minister said: This is all speculation. The Prime Minister has been clear that we are making good progress on the future relationship and 95 percent of the withdrawal agreement is now settled and negotiations are ongoing.

title: BBC Weather London UK latest Met Office weather forecast winter cold
story: BBC Weather forecaster Ben Rich said temperatures will hit the high teens on Sunday as mild southerly winds push out the freezing temperatures.He said: &ldquoFrost is not a word I will be using at all in this week ahead forecast. I do have some wind and some rain for you, though.My Rich referenced an area of low pressure during the BBC&rsquos long-range forecast on Friday and said: &ldquoThis swirl of cloud was Hurricane Oscar.&ldquoIt&rsquos not a hurricane anymore but it is still a fairly deep area of low pressure and it is going to be steered to the north-west of the UK by the jet stream.                UK weather forecast: SHOCK chart shows Britain set to face FREEZE                UK weather forecast: Yellow weather WARNING in force - travel chaos&ldquoThat will mean that it&rsquoll be northern and western areas that see the wettest and windiest of the weather through the weekend.&ldquoFurther south and east you are, on the other side of the jet stream, a better chance that you will stay dry and see some sunshine.The BBC host also warned the wind speed on Saturday afternoon could reach as high as 60 miles per hour across the western side of Scotland.The southerly winds will bring with them some milder air, with temperatures generally 15C and parts of north-east Scotland expected to hit 17C.BBC Weather: Temperatures set to reach 17C in London (Image: Met Office)Into Saturday evening when bonfire celebrations are expected to begin, Mr Rich said: &ldquoStill some outbreaks of rain for some western and central areas &ndash particularly Cardiff could see some rain for any fireworks displays, for example.&ldquoIt will be quite windy but it will stay pretty mild. And as we go into the second half of the weekend low pressure will still be dominating the scene, moving to north-west and this will leave us with mild southwesterly winds adds still our weather front moving slowly and still, at this stage, likely to be bringing some rain across parts of the&nbspsouth west, fringing into Wales and the West Midlands.&ldquoIn fact, turning very wet across the south west of England later in the day.The BBC Weather presenter said it will &ldquostill be relatively mild on Sunday night and into Monday morning.Mr Rich said temperatures could continue to heat up on Monday, adding: &ldquoIt does look like low pressure will, again, be sitting generally to the western side of the UK. And at this stage, if the wind direction is just right, eastern areas could get into some very mild air indeed.The BBC host said it would hit 17C in London on Monday and into double figures &ldquoeverywhere you look.But the weather could take a U-turn on Tuesday as another area of low pressure approaches Britain once again and unleashes heavy rainfall and strong winds.&nbspHe said: &ldquoAs we head towards the end of the week the jet stream will still for a time be keeping weather systems to the western side of the UK.&ldquoBut there is a chance that as we get towards next weekend the jet stream might break through a little bit more and allow weather systems to slide a bit further east so bringing some rain a bit further east.&ldquoIf that happens we could start to tap into some cooler air. But actually it looks on balance like it will stay with a mild feel.Mr Rich added: &ldquoGenerally speaking, the chill is over &ndash&nbspfor now.The Met Office also said the jet stream will trigger a heat up in temperatures in Britain over the weekend. The Met Office forecast reads: &ldquoThe jet stream lies across the UK this weekend, bringing unsettled weather to many of us.&ldquoThis will also bring mildewing air across the UK from the south. The jet stream will continue to draw mild air from the south into mid-week.Met Office meteorologist Aidan McGivern told viewers: Into next week, it will turn considerably milder. We will lose the frosty mornings.This Saturday has a big upward spike across the UK well into next week and beyond. Eventually, the rain disappears too by Monday.The low pressure will move into the west of the UK throughout next week, with high pressure to the east.Britain will be drawing up this very mild air from the southwest. Temperatures will continue to be above average next week.There could be bouts of wind and rain between Wednesday and Friday - but the high pressure will have a big impact next Saturday.Next weekend looks set to be a very mild couple of days. So, it will continue to be above average, continue to be mild into next week.

title: modern slavery middle east
story: The -year-old mother-of-four - who had gone to Jordan to find domestic work so she could send money back home to her children - had been left covered in  per cent of burns after she was attacked by her employer.Mary is one of .million women who have moved to Middle Eastern countries such as Jordan, Saudi Arabia and Lebanon from the African continent to work as maids.Unable to read and lacking qualications due to little education, these women seek jobs working as domestic servants for rich families, hoping to send money home.However, as a new BBC documentary - Maid in Hell - reveals, they are forced to work for years without pay in unsafe conditions, badly beaten, starved, and even raped by their employers.This is all due to the Kafala system - a set of laws governing migrant labour in the Middle East which binds workers to their bosses.Mary had travelled to Jordan  months earlier to work for a wealthy family and make money to send back to her husband and children.But when she arrived her passport and mobile phone were taken off her, and she was forced to work -hour days - cooking and cleaning from am to late into the night.The mother and daughter would often beat her - but things escalated when Mary was in the kitchen making a cup of tea and a gas canister exploded, setting her clothes, chest and lower body on fire.It caused her to pass out, and when she came round her boss was kicking her while hurtling insults at her, causing further injuries.Her screams attracted the attention of a neighbour who called the police but they just turned a blind eye.Instead, Mary spent  days in a hospital in Jordans capital city, Amman.Her boss told Marys husband that his we had had a minor accident, but was in good health.It was only when it looked like she was unlikely to recover that she was sent back to Kenya to die.Despite efforts to save Mary, her burns were too severe and she passed away, leaving her four children without a mother.In the documentary, Kenyan Senator Emma Mbura tries to retrieve promised wages as compensation for Marys family - but is met with laughter from her fellow politicians.In , a Saudi couple came under fire from international human rights groups after they hammered  heated nails into their maids hand when she complained to them about the heavy workload.After increased reports such as these, in  the Kenyan government banned its citizens from working in Saudi Arabia, Jordan and Lebanon.However, women still under the impression that there would be lucrative work out there, travelled illegally, meeting recruitment agents who would match them with employers.As well as beatings and withholding money, rape and sexual abuse are common.Jessica, from Kenya, says her master came into her bedroom when she was sleeping.I said no, Im married, but he told me I had to obey the rules in his house, she says.Eventually, tired of the sexual abuse, she tied three bed sheets together to climb down from the third floor and escape to a refuge for former maids.When askedshe was scared of dying or becoming injured, she said that dying was better than going through what I was going through.The documentary makers also speak to Maher Doumit, who has worked as a recruitment agent in Lebanon and Jordan for  years.He is unrepentant about his job, insisting that he has done nothing wrong.Human rights dont exist in this world, no way, he says. Maybe in Europe, but not the Middle East.I will not stop this business because I am helping myself and other people.Viewers see Maher meet Paulina and Rita, two young women from Ghana who have travelled to the Lebanon to work.Maher says he likes to recruit Ghanaian women as they are harder workers.When the pair are forced to hand over their passports and phones, they are nervous.Paulina has a baby son, and worries about how she is going to contact her family without a mobile phone. Its a fear for me, she admits.The pair are also taken for medical checks, to ensure they are fit and well enough to put in the gruelling shts their employers will demand.“Sometimes a girl comes over from her country,she’s pregnant or she’s sick, this is a big problem,” says Maher.When the tests come back clear, the girls are placed with a family - and Maher gets his commission. The figure is undisclosed, but hes raking enough cash to buy himself a three-bedroom apartment in an upmarket area of Beirut - which go for around £,.In , the bodies of two domestic workers were sent back to their country every week from Lebanon.A report showed  per cent of these were due to suicide, while others died from injuries inflicted on them by their employers, malnutrition and failed escape attempts - usually from climbing out of a window.This report makes us look like devils, Maher says.Although Senator Mbura has started a grassroots campaign to help the victims of modern slavery in the Middle East, without help from her fellow politicians she is limited in what she can do.Its like a cartel, she admits. Its just like drugs, its a business. It cannot stop.Marys case was thrown out of a Jordanian court after the judge ruled her death was a result of fate and destiny.Her employers identity was never released meaning more women will have been sent to work for her, and her family never received a penny.Even her passport was never ed. The United Nations recently called for an end to the Kafala system, but in  the Saudi working ban for Kenyans was formally revoked, and Kenya are currently working on new agreements with Jordan and Lebanon.It means women like Mary will continue to spend months and years suffering in silence.Maid in Hell: Why Slavery is on Sunday  November, BBC Two at pmOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: sajid javid home office amber rudd sun says
story: His Home Office seems more dysal now even than when a large chunk of it was condemned as “not fit for purpose”  years ago.His junior minister and civil servants seem clueless about their own post-Brexit immigration policy.His predecessor Amber Rudd was given such woeful advice by two ­bungling senior officials she had to resign after repeating it.Mr Javid himself is having to be warned against the disastrous error of expanding “hate crime” to include ageism and misogyny.Britain is being engulfed by a tsunami of violence. Gang warfare has exploded on our streets. We need a Home Secretary resolute about REAL offences — stabbings, muggings, burglaries and so on — not inventing new ones to show how liberal and erse he is.Our police chiefs HAVE had a sudden conversion to “core policing” this week. That is welcome,years too late.The Home Secretary must enforce this new focus nationwide, alongside his many other problems. Getting crime back down, reasserting law and order and fixing the shambolic Home Office could be the making of him.Mr Javid needs to shape up.THE idea that the police probe into Nigel Farage’s backer Arron Banks invalidates Brexit is a desperate stunt​ even by Remainers’ standards.They must know that Vote Leave, the official cross-party campaign, wanted nothing to do with Banks’ disruptive, self-promoting Leave.EU outfit.Nor did many voters. Which is why Leave’s support fell dramatically in polls when Leave.EU unveiled its toxic anti-migrant poster. Many waverers reluctantly opted for Remain to avoid siding with Farage and Banks. And Vote Leave still won by ,,.Imagine how much greater the margin would have been, in a nation staunchly Eurosceptic for decades, had Banks not been involved. Greater still had the Government not blown £million of our cash, outside of campaign spending, leafleting every home on Remain’s behalf.And it would be even widera second referendum was somehow brought about.To suggest that .million Leavers were swayed by dirty tricks and allegedly dodgy spending is utterly absurd.THE Government simply cannot afford to betray the DUP’s red lines on Brexit.They must not under-estimate unionist resolve. title: devon man ron easton lay dying roof three days
story: Ron Easton was found in a gulley on his flat roof at his home in Bigbury-on-Sea, south Devon, on October .His neighbour raised the alarm after a build up of full milk bottles and papers at his front door.It is believed the former racing driver - known locally as Ton Up Ron - fell while attempting to fix his TV aerial.He was taken to Plymouths Derrord Hospital where his family revealed he died on Friday.Ron was a private man but earned the nickname because of his love of cars.Before his accident he would still be seen driving around in his blue MG sports car.A flag in the village has been lowered to half mast with a tribute to Ron aged -and-a-half.Louise Wainwright, editor of the local Bigbury Newsletter, said: Ron was a very private man. Its very sad.Hazel Osborne, who watched the rescue operation told PlymouthLive : Hes an incredible old boy who still drives his MG sports car. He was a rally driver who once drove in the Dakar rally.It was her friend who raised the alarm, she said: The fire service and ambulance were here. There were paramedics and first responders and then the Devon Air Ambulance arrived and you could see clouds of dust.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: corbyn ally councils buy homes
story: Corbynista Lloyd Russell-Moyle believes town hall chiefs should be given power of first refusal on any house up for sale.And he wants to tear up planning laws to allow them to build high-rise flats in posh suburbs and leafy villages.Mr Russell-Moyle, , revealed his party will order mass compulsory purchases of former council homes sold off under the Tories’ Right To Buy scheme.But he told a Labour rally: “Let’s not just talk about council houses — let’s get those bloody private houses back into our hands.”The Brighton Kemptown MP — an ally of Jeremy Corbyn — is urging the Labour leader to take swathes of privately-owned property into public control.Left-wing activists cheered as he unveiled his plan at an anti-austerity conference under the banner “Stand With Corbyn”.Mr Russell-Moyle said a future Labour government would abolish the right to buy and “compulsory purchase en masse” sold-off housing stock.He told the London rally: “We need to develop a system that slowly over time takes property out of private hands and puts it into public hands.“For example, why not give every council the first right of refusal with any houses put up for sale “And I don’t mean a former council house — I mean your private house.”A Tory MP last night called it “pure madness”.Ex-housing minister Grant Shapps said: “The truth’s out — cuddly Corbyn wants to nationalise your home.”If voters needed any reminding of the Marxist-inspired madness that would descend after a Corbyn victory, Brighton MP Lloyd Russell-Moyle has provided it.The ‘right to buy’ revolution, letting people buy their council houses, was the bedrock of Margaret Thatcher’s premiership.It enabled millions to gain a stake in society which they could then pass on to their children.But under the alarming vision of this MP, the clock would be turned back to an era of mass state ownership of property that has chilling echoes of the former Soviet Union.Not content with giving town halls the powers to compulsorily purchase ex council houses, he also wants to see them get first refusal on any private homes that come on the market.Although not official Labour policy, the MP was cheered to the rafters at a rally.So make no mistake, it shows the thinking of the loony left who surround Corbyn and would have the whip handLabour gained power.There is a shortage of affordable housing in the UK, but mass ‘nationalisation’ of private property is not the solution.Where there is home ownership, there are people creating communities.It’s a cherished value that Jezza’s jesters should not be allowed to put in peril. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: foreign investors brexit liam fox opinion
story: People want to buy our world-class British products and companies want to use our services.And investors want to put their money into the UK because, like us, they know that they are investing in a country that is set to prosper as we leave the EU.New figures from the internationally respected organisation UNCTADshowed that during the first six months of , only China secured more inward investment into their country than the UK.According to the UN, China secured billion, the UK .billion and the US .billion. The Netherlands and Spain were the only other EU countries in the top ten.That is some achievement for the UK. And demonstrates that the people who know where to invest, know it should be in the UK.They know we live in a dynamic nation, brimming with potential.So as we leave the European Union, we should remember the many reasons investors choose to put their money here in the United Kingdom, which is one of the world’s largest and most successful economies.We are at record levels of employment. Our success is underpinned by a legal system whose reputation is second to none. We have a skilled workforce and a low tax and a well-regulated economy.We are home to some of the finest universities, our research and development capabilities are cutting-edge and our financial institutions world-leading.We are in the right time zone to trade with Asia in the morning and the United States in the afternoon — and, of course, we speak English, the language of global business.Plus, there is serious global momentum behind businesses in the UK. We continue to attract more Foreign Direct Investmentthan anywhere  in Europe. And we are the number one choice in Europe for key strategic investments, such as headquarters. So it’s easy to see why more than , new businesses start up here every day.And it isn’t just small and medium-sized businesses. The UK has created  of Europe’s  companies valued at more than billion.Only this week Monzo, the British bank which operates through an app on your phone, secured £million of investment in order to double its workforce. This raised the company’s value to the £billion mark just three years after its formation.This is a fantastic vote of confidence in the UK and yet another sign that we have plenty to be optimistic about after we leave the EU.Investment creates jobs across all parts of the UK, pumps money into our communities and improves the lives of millions of people.Last year, FDI created , new jobs in the UK as well as safeguarding another ,.One reason we are seeing so much success is that this government has built an environment that makes investment and job creation easy.We are champions of free trade and we actively encourage businesses of all sizes — from start-ups to large corporations — to build trading links in all corners of the world.This weekend I’ll be representing the UK at the China International Import Expo in Shanghai where we are a “country of honour”.Over recent months, China has started to open up its market for UK goods and services, including dairy products, potatoes and petrol stations.And, this weekend, we intend to build on these achievements and create even more exciting opportunities for British companies.We also possess world-class talent. For example, we excel at research and development, which means that overseas companies want to tap into British expertise to advance the quality of their products. In last week’s Budget, we announced a further £.billion to strengthen the UK’s global leadership in science and innovation — that brings the total to £billion invested in research and development since .We want a partnership with business to make our country prosper.The Government’s Industrial Strategy includes innovative deals agreed with inidual sectors to attract investment. We are already reaping the rewards.The global marketplace never slows and we, too, must never stand still.Building on our impressive investment success, I have implemented the High Potential Opportunities scheme, which will deliver growth where it is most needed, often to previously overlooked areas.The success of the AgriTech programme in the West Midlands town of Telford and Leicestershire’s leading space sector cluster are proof the benefits of global investment are being felt in every part of the country.Over recent months, the Department for International Trade has led a series of investment roundtables, promoting UK industry to a global audience and driving foreign direct-investment into the UK as we prepare to leave the European Union.So far, these events have centred on tech, le sciences, automotive and agri-tech sectors and will soon start to focus on areas such as the creative industries.Initiatives such as this are going to be key in the coming months as we develop the UK’s own independent trade policy for the first time in more than  years.Working with businesses in the UK and overseas, I am determined to continue generating this flow of good news.But the facts tell a dferent story: Confidence in Britain is riding so high around the world that foreign investors are betting on it like never before.New UN figures show that in the first six months of  we were second only to booming China in attracting investment.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: ghost town shops community hubs
story: Boarded-up shops will be converted into gyms, tearooms, youth clubs and advice centres to breathe new le into “ghost towns”.Ministers hope the “open doors” project will attract people back into dying city centres – and spark a mini-revival for traders.Under the plan, landlords of disused shop units will be teamed up with community groups offering key services to younger and older people.Teams of experts will help strike temporary contract deals to get the high street buzzing once again.It is hoped the move will also cut crime and tackle other urban problems such as unemployment and loneliness.That is why this week I am launching the Open Doors project to help regenerate the high street and support community groups. I recognise these challenges are linked.Our communities and our high streets will not be left behind.Communities Secretary James Brokenshire will reveal full details of when he launches a massive regeneration plan on Wednesday.More than , jobs have been lost in town centres over the past three years as the rise of internet shopping drove major retail firms to the wall.Last year alone, the high street lost a total of , shops, with major chains such as House of Fraser and BHS falling into administration and retail giants like MS closing branches.Bosses blame the rise of Amazon and other online shopping sites – whose overheads are much lower - for driving shoppers away from town centres.High Streets were given £.billion of help in last week’s Budget, including a cut in business rates for small shopkeepers, relaxation of planning laws and special funding to help transform town centres.A  of experts has been assembled to find other ways of helping town centres to survive the internet age – and carve out a new future.Their blueprint for future high streets will be published soon.Mr Brokenshire said: “I’m determined that our communities and our high streets will not be left behind.“Last week, the Budget provided a raft of measures to redevelop shops and help town centres adapt.Small retailers will see their business rates bills cut by a third, saving them up to £ million over two years.“These actions will help create a more level playing field for all retailers.”Communities Secretary James Brokenshire today tells us of his plan to regenerate town centres.But he can’t afford to be woolly or lacking in detail, and few will be convinced that a £million injection into a ‘Future High Street Fund’ will be enough to hold back the tsunami of the internet age.Good luck, Minister, but give us concrete solutions, not mealy-mouthed platitudes.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: kate winslet labelled hero by family of gemma nuttall
story: Winslet joined grieving family and friends at the funeral of brave mum Gemma Nuttall who turned down chemotherapy to save her unborn baby’s le.Gemma, , from Rossendale, Lancashire, lost her five-year battle with oian cancer last month.Hollywood superstar Kate had stepped in to help the mum-of-one raise the funds she needed for immunotherapy and initially the treatment had been a success.But the cancer ed and the dental nurse, who leaves behind four-year-old daughter Penelope, was moved to Pendleside Hospice in Burnley earlier in October, where she passed away.Gemma’s mum Helen Sproates told : “Kate really supported my daughter and helped her.Whenever Gemma was down she’d text her and bolster her up. She’s very strong – and we needed that strength.Gemmas devastated mum Helen Sproates paid tribute to her ‘angel’ daughter saying: My world will never be the same again.She added: She would genuinely help anybodyshe could, she was just like an angel.“Kate lost her own mum to liver cancer, so for her to put that on the back burner and support us must have been really hard as she’s still grieving herself.“I know she found it hard, but she did it anyway. That’s an amazing human being who can do something like that.”Kate visited Gemma in hospital during her final days, staying at her bedside.Speaking about her relationship with little girl Penelope, Helen told The Rossendale Free Press: They were so alike, very cheeky characters, like two peas in a pod and just watching them together was just beautul. That’s not going to happen anymore.Mourners wore blue and pink at Accrington Cemetery to celebrate Gemmas le.Winslet, whose own mother was going through cancer treatment at the same time, said it was tragically sad and sent her love to Gemmas family.She told The Lancashire : It is a privilege to be able to give Gemma the send-off she deserves at the end of her incredible fight.“As a young mum Gemma’s extraordinary determination to beat her cancer for Penelope was something that deeply moved me and made me want to help.“She was so clearly a fighter. She fought her battle and against all odds she kept proving them wrong.“The fundraising had been a phenomenal success and Helen’s initial efforts to send Gemma to Germany for immunotherapy treatment hadn’t been in vain. For a while it worked.The Titanic star added: But even though that has not been the case and even though Gemma didn’t quite make it to , she did make it to Penelope’s first second, third and fourth birthdays and to her first day of big school.“They were also able to have some magical memories together which doctors thought would be impossible.“In truth Gemma lived for at least  months longer than her specialists believed. She had more time with her family.”Gemmas mother, Helen Sproates, confirmed her daughters death in a post on Facebook.The family have formed the Gemma Rose Foundation so they can help others.Ms Nuttalls mother, Ms Sproates, said: It is with an utterly broken heart that I have to tell you all that my beautul warrior lost her battle early this morning.We fought so hard but we just couldnt do it anymore – I am one very proud but devastated mum right now.Sleep tight Gemma - My world will never be the same again.She also wrote: “She was always putting others before ­herself. She was a kind and thoughtful daughter with a caring nature.“Most of all she loved her special little Penelope and was a fantastic mummy.  Penelope has been her rock and her reason to keep going as long as she did.“It is heartbreaking to know ­Penelope is now  having to grow up without her mummy’s love.”Gemma first learned she had aggressive oian cancer at her -week scan and was offered a termination so she could start le-saving treatment.But she chose to delay any treatment until after the birth of her daughter Penelope and after the birth doctors were able to remove the oian tumour.She began a gruelling round of chemotherapy while her baby battled for her le in intensive care.After initially beating the illness, Gemma said she enjoyed getting in to a routine and got a job as a trainee manager at her mum’s soft play business, Funtazia in Blackburn.But sadly, a year later, her cancer ed and after rounds of chemotherapy and radiotherapy, doctors said little could be done to save her.Gemmas mum Helen had read about immunotherapy, which boosts the bodys natural defences, available at the Hallwang Clinic in Germany.The -year-old sold her house and started a fundraising page to raise further donations to cover the cost of the huge cost of the therapy.Gemma flew to Germany last May and began a six-session course, which costs up to £, a time, but only had enough funds for the first round.In July, Helen received an email from Kate Winslets PA saying she wanted to offer her support and had contacted her Titanic co-star Leonardo Di Caprio for help.The pair auctioned themselves off for three dates at DiCaprios annual fundraising event and raised . million , which they were able to also give to other charities.Gemma got the all-clear at the start of this year and in February appeared on This Morning to revisit the amazing moment the -year-old actress offered to help pay for her treatment.Hosts Holly Willoughby and Philip Schofield then surprised the brave mum as they revealed the Hollywood star was on the other end of the phone.Winslet said: I lost my own mother last year in May to oian cancer and we as a family were given a very poor prognosis for my mum.After a four year battle... we decided to look where and we also stumbled across those places in Germany.Simultaneously I came across [Gemmas] petition campaigning to have immunotherapy made available on the NHS and my heart sunk as at that point.I thought this poor young woman is probably years away from her being able to access that kind of treatment on the national health service.I found her Go Fund Me page and I saw how much she needed to raise and at that point there was only £, in the fund and I just thought I cannot have this happen.My own mother was very, very, very unwell and I just though my mum would be very gratefulI could do this for someone , another young mum.We got close to £, and I thought, right its time to call my friend Leo.I phoned Leo and I said do you think that we could do a charity dinner or something and he said lets go one better, come with me to Saint Tropez to my benefit fundraiser and we will auction off a dinner with Jack and Rose.Gemma had viewers in tears as she told the actress: Thank you so much for all your hard work and me being able to have my treatment that I really did need. You saved my le.

title: record payouts school compensation
story: They included a youngster who tripped over a tree branch and another who got an arm trapped behind a hot radiator.Payouts were made on  compensation claims in England last year — costing taxpayers £.million.The toll was up ten per cent on £.million in , figures released under Freedom of Information laws revealed.The branch-trip pupil in St Helens, Merseyside, was paid £,.Northumberland County Council handed out £, for the radiator accident and a separate £, for a leg fracture from “a bucket swing”.In Halton, Merseyside, a pupil got £, after losing a tooth in a collision with a student during a PE lesson.A trampolining incident that left a pupil injured in Southampton led to a £, payout.And a youngster hurt tripping over a speed bump at school was paid £, by Derby County Council.While accepting that some payouts are justied, John O’Connell of the TaxPayers’ Alliance said: “Council compensation culture is costing taxpayers dear.“Every penny that goes on settlements or costlier insurance is cash that can’t be spent on essential services.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: right to buy labour party the sun on sunday says
story: If voters needed any reminding of the Marxist-inspired madness that would descend after a Corbyn victory, Brighton MP Lloyd Russell-Moyle has provided it.The ‘right to buy’ revolution, letting people buy their council houses, was the bedrock of Margaret Thatcher’s premiership.It enabled millions to gain a stake in society which they could then pass on to their children.But under the alarming vision of this MP, the clock would be turned back to an era of mass state ownership of property that has chilling echoes of the former Soviet Union.Not content with giving town halls the powers to compulsorily purchase ex council houses, he also wants to see them get first refusal on any private homes that come on the market.Although not official Labour policy, the MP was cheered to the rafters at a rally.So make no mistake, it shows the thinking of the loony left who surround Corbyn and would have the whip handLabour gained power.There is a shortage of affordable housing in the UK, but mass ‘nationalisation’ of private property is not the solution.Where there is home ownership, there are people creating communities.It’s a cherished value that Jezza’s jesters should not be allowed to put in peril.THE death of the high street is a disfiguring scar on the landscape.So the Government’s injection of cash to counter internet shopping is laudable.Communities Secretary James Brokenshire today tells us of his plan to regenerate town centres.But he can’t afford to be woolly or lacking in detail, and few will be convinced that a £million injection into a ‘Future High Street Fund’ will be enough to hold back the tsunami of the internet age.Good luck, Minister, but give us concrete solutions, not mealy-mouthed platitudes.DOOM-laden Remoaners say this country is facing the economic scrapheap after Brexit.But the facts tell a dferent story: Confidence in Britain is riding so high around the world that foreign investors are betting on it like never before.New UN figures show that in the first six months of  we were second only to booming China in attracting investment.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
